★★★★½

Titanic is James Cameron’s insane, glorious, 195-minute love letter to doomed romance, human hubris, and the sheer power of big-budget filmmaking, and somehow every single minute of it still works like gangbusters twenty-eight years later.

This isn’t just a disaster movie; it’s a time machine. From the moment that sweeping aerial shot glides over the pristine ship in 1912, accompanied by James Horner’s heartbreaking flute motif, you’re completely gone. The recreation of the ship itself is so obsessive, so jaw-droppingly perfect, that you can smell the fresh paint and feel the Atlantic wind. Cameron makes you fall in love with every detail (the grand staircase, the third-class party below deck, the wireless room frantically sending CQD) so that when the iceberg hits and the water starts rising, the loss feels personal.

Leonardo DiCaprio and Kate Winslet at 22 and 21 years old deliver two of the most electric, lived-in performances in blockbuster history. Jack and Rose aren’t just pretty faces; they’re class warfare, freedom vs. cage, life vs. slow death by etiquette, and their chemistry is so palpable you can practically feel the steam on the fogged-up Renault in the cargo hold. Every stolen glance, every "I’m flying" moment, every quiet "You jump, I jump" promise lands like a gut punch.

Then the last hour hits and Cameron goes full merciless god: the water rising, the band playing "Nearer My God to Thee," the mother reading to her children in steerage, the old couple holding each other in bed, the 1,500 souls slipping beneath the waves while Rose floats on that door… it’s still one of the most overwhelming cinematic guttings ever filmed.

It loses half a star only because some of the modern-day framing scenes with Old Rose feel a little corny now, and a couple of lines ("Party of the century!") make you wince. But honestly? Who cares.

Four and a half stars: one for the romance that defined a generation, one for the most spectacular disaster sequence in film history, one for the technical wizardry that still looks flawless, and one because every single time "My Heart Will Go On" swells over those final credits, grown adults turn into sobbing teenagers again.

Titanic isn’t just a movie. It’s the reason half the planet knows what an iceberg warning sounds like.

I have to say that the movie itself lags. There's not much you can do with a movie that is about a ship that sinks. They tried to make an interesting story, but it just turned into a cheesy romance, which adds to the movie's lag. Plus, the characters themselves were, in my opinion, unlikable.

Rude Yankees using perverse robot technology, to dig into a sunken ship. Finding a nude drawing. Then comes an old woman, who survived the shipwreck. And it's her. Personally I would have left everything down there, and I also prefer men. So, it would have been extremely more interesting to see a nude drawing of Dicaprio. There's also this unbelievable class gap, that of course let the working class people drown. While there's still a chance for the capital owners to survive. The scene with Dicaprio tied up, and the water's rising, I feel is a cheap, suspence thing. I find it also a bit strange that the couple couldn't hold on to the raft together. All in all, it's not inspiring to me.

9.5/10 The film's occasionally clunky dialogue draws some questionable looks, but that's the biggest problem I got. With that out of the way, I say this movie was James Cameron at his peak. With his deep passion and huge ambitions, he crafted a work so timeless, grand, and spellbinding that it still stood nearly 30 years later as a giant in the world of blockbuster filmmaking. It may not be perfect, but it's still a work of great excellence. It's something I don't see Hollywood making ever again.
